                                                                                                                                 "Picco"   a Member   of   the Temperance   Society.   159
                                                                                                                                 of
                                                                                                                                  the dogs."   " Hector," who was
                                                                                                                          rest                                      present, and
                                                                                                                          overheard the conversation, was missing next morning,
                                                                                                                          and when Hogg reached Bowerhope, there was " Hec
                                                                                                                              "
                                                                                                                          tor   sitting on a knoll, waiting his arrival. He had
                                                                                                                          swum across a flooded river to reach the spot.
                                                                                                                                 "PICCO:" A MEMBER OF THE TEMPERANCE        SOCIETY.
                                                                                                                             Piccolo, or " Picco," the beautiful dog belonging to
                                                                                                                          the Rev. Henry de Bunsen, of Dorrington Rectory (for
                                                                                                                          merly of Lilleshall, Shropshire), is of the Pomeranian
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          breed, commonly known in England by the name of
                                                                                                                          "
                                                                                                                            Spitz." He was born in the year 1865, in the village
                                                                                                                          of Edgmond, near Newport.          His parents, both fine
                                                                                                                          dogs with silky white hair, are still alive, and greatly
                                                                                                                          valued by their owner, Miss Alcock.       When "Picco"
                                                                                                                          came to Lilleshall, he was a small, fluffy, white puppy
                                                                                                                          of six weeks — snowy white, and very much like the
                                                                                                                          toy lambs you can see in the shops.       His first devel
                                                                                                                          opment of character showed itself in his being con
                                                                                                                          stantly on the alert, and always ready to bark his little
                                                                                                                          shrill bark if he heard any footstep outside the door.
                                                                                                                          His education during the first six months of his life
                                                                                                                          proceeded very rapidly. He learned to beg in a few
                                                                                                                          lessons, and with little difficulty waited until ten was
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          counted before he would eat the biscuit put before him.
                                                                                                                          There was usually a pet cat or two in the room with
                                                                                                                                           "
                                                                                                                          him, so " Picco easily got over the canine aversion to
                                                                                                                          cats.   Miss Pussy, indeed, became very fond of rubbing
                                                                                                                          her nose against him, and frequently followed him

                                                                                                                          160                Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                          about the garden.      From being constantly in attend
                                                                                                                          ance at the family meals, "Picco" soon got to know
                                                                                                                          the sound of his favorite biscuit, and he has also learned
                                                                                                                          never to come and beg for it till after his own dinner,
                                                                                                                          which is given him after the family have dined. The
                                                                                                                          only exception he makes to this rule is on his "tub-
                                                                                                                          day," when he fancies that he has an additional appe
                                                                                                                          tite after his bath ; and so on that day he comes regu
                                                                                                                          larly to be fed at luncheon.
                                                                                                                              When his own dinner of rice and scraps is prepared,
                                                                                                                          and some one calls out " ' Picco,' go and fetch your
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          table-cloth," he gets up and walks to the sideboard cup
                                                                                                                          board, which he opens with his nose, and brings out a
                                                                                                                          copy of The Times newspaper in his mouth, which is
                                                                                                                          laid on the carpet. On this paper table-cloth his plate
                                                                                                                          is placed.    He then begs, looking slyly out of the cor
                                                                                                                          ners of his eyes to see when the finger goes down as
                                                                                                                          the word ten is pronounced.       He then daintily smells
                                                                                                                          all round the plate to see if his dinner pleases him ;
                                                                                                                          very often this is not the case, and only by dint of coax
                                                                                                                                           " Puss,
                                                                                                                          ing, or calling          puss," can he be induced to eat
                                                                                                                          his dinner.    When that is accomplished he is told to
                                                                                                                          fetch his biscuits, when he trots to the kitchen and
                                                                                                                          picks up a covered basket, which he brings to Mrs. de
                                                                                                                          Bunsen, and throws it down with a bang by her side.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          He will stand up by her side while she puts a piece of
                                                                                                                          biscuit in front of him, saying " Trust," and, till he hears
                                                                                                                          the words " Eat it," he will not even dare to look at the
                                                                                                                          tempting morsel.     Then   he will dance on his hind legs
                                                                                                                          and walk round      the   room for a piece of biscuit or

                                                                                                                                 "Picco": a Member of   the Temperance   Society.   161
                                                                                                                          bread, and hold it on his nose till his mistress counts
                                                                                                                          ten, when he lifts it off with his two fore paws.   But
                                                                                                                          the most remarkable trait in "Picco.s" character is his
                                                                                                                          great dislike of any kind of wine or beer.      He knows
                                                                                                                          the look of a wine-glass, and nothing will induce him
                                                                                                                          even to smell it! In the kitchen he refuses to drink
                                                                                                                          out of any tumbler offered him there, with but one ex
                                                                                                                          ception ; for, strange to say, he will walk straight up to
                                                                                                                          and drink out of the glass of the teetotal house-maid,
                                                                                                                          for he knows that she only drinks water! Peter, the
                                                                                                                          butler, always has him to sleep in his room at night,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          where he sleeps very soundly till awakened by the
                                                                                                                          alarum at six o'clock.      When Peter gets up, then
                                                                                                                          "Picco" stirs himself, and goes into the next room,
                                                                                                                          where the. groom sleeps, on whose bed he jumps, and
                                                                                                                          pulls off   theclothes till the inmate rises. "Picco"
                                                                                                                          knows Sunday quite well, and never offers to go to
                                                                                                                          church with the family, though he flies after them if
                                                                                                                          he sees any of them putting on their out-door things
                                                                                                                          on any other day. He also never barks at the Sun
                                                                                                                          day-school children who come into the house to their
                                                                                                                          classes, though one footstep on a week-day makes
                                                                                                                          him furious.   When the family are away, "Picco" will
                                                                                                                          never take a walk with strangers; he keeps company
                                                                                                                          only with those who live in the house.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                            At  the annual meeting of the Lilleshall Temperance
                                                                                                                          Society in June last, we had the pleasure of seeing
                                                                                                                          "Picco." The dog was on the platform, much to the
                                                                                                                          amusement of all present. One of the speakers, in
                                                                                                                          referring to "Picco's" firmness in his water-drinking

                                                                                                                          1   62             Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                          habits, asked,   "Is   not   'Picco' worthy of   being enrolled
                                                                                                                          as a member       of   the   Lilleshall Temperance Society   ?"
                                                                                                                                                                 "
                                                                                                                          Amidst loud and hearty cheers, Yes, yes," resounded
                                                                                                                          from all parts of the large assembly.  The next morn
                                                                                                                          ing we had the pleasure of visiting the clean and tidy
                                                                                                                          cottages   of several of the Lilleshall
                                                                                                                                                              miners in company
                                                                                                                          with their devoted friend, Miss Battersby, when one of
                                                                                                                          the miners met us on the road, and, politely touching
                                                                                                                          his hat, said, "/ hope, sir, that     I
                                                                                                                                                            shall keep from the
                                                                                                                          drink as true as that dog 'Picco !'"
                                                                                                                             Ah ! what a change would come over thousands of
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          homes that are now scenes of sorrow and desolation
                                                                                                                          if men and women were all as wise as " Picco !" —
                                                                                                                          Band of Hope Review.
                                                                                                                                 "BEZERILLO" REFUSES TO HURT THE INDIAN WOMAN.
                                                                                                                               Southey, in his "         of the West Indies,"
                                                                                                                                                   History                          gives
                                                                                                                          the following narration       :
                                                                                                                             "
                                                                                                                             Though only a dog, the full pay of a cross-bow
                                                                                                                          man, and half as much more, was received by his own
                                                                                                                          er for his services, and he was thought to have done as
                                                                                                                          much towards what is called the pacification of that
                                                                                                                          island as a third of all the Spaniards who were em
                                                                                                                          ployed in it.  'Bezerillo' was his name; of a reddish
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          color, with a black face, not large of his kind, nor fine
                                                                                                                          ly made, but of great understanding and courage ; and,
                                                                                                                          indeed, what he did was such that, sans doute, the
                                                                                                                          Christians believed God had sent him for their succor.
                                                                                                                          He would select among two hundred Indians one who

                                                                                                                                     "Bezerillo" refuses to hurt the Indian Woman.   163
                                                                                                                          had escaped from the Christians, or who should have
                                                                                                                          been pointed out to him, and would seize him by the
                                                                                                                          arm and make him come back with him to the camp,
                                                                                                                          or wherever the Christians might be ; and if he at
                                                                                                                          tempted to resist, or would not come, he tore him to
                                                                                                                          pieces, and did other things which were very remarka
                                                                                                                          ble, and worthy of admiration.   At midnight, if a pris
                                                                                                                          oner got loose, and were a league distant, it was but to
                                                                                                                          say, The Indian is gone !' or, ' Fetch him !. and away
                                                                                                                                 '
                                                                                                                          'Bezerillo' went upon the scent and brought him back.
                                                                                                                          The tame Indians he knew as well as a man could
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          know them, and never did them hurt; and among
                                                                                                                          many tame ones, he could distinguish one wild one.
                                                                                                                          It seemed as if he had the judgment and intelligence
                                                                                                                          of a man, and that not a foolish one. Salazar had one
                                                                                                                          day taken an old Indian woman among other prison
                                                                                                                          ers, after a defeat of the natives, and for no assigned
                                                                                                                          or assignable reason, but in mere wantonness of cruel
                                                                                                                          ty, he determined to set this dog upon the poor wretch.
                                                                                                                          But it was to make a sport, or a spectacle for the Span
                                                                                                                          iards, or the Christians, as their contemporary historian
                                                                                                                          and fellow-Christian calls them, even while he is re
                                                                                                                          lating this story. Salazar gave the woman an old let
                                                                                                                          ter, and told her to go off with it immediately to the
                                                                                                                          Governor at Aymaco.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                             "
                                                                                                                               The poor creature went her way joyfully, expect
                                                                                                                          ing to be set at liberty when she had performed her
                                                                                                                          errand.    The intent was merely to get her away from
                                                                                                                          the rest, that the dog might have a fair field, and the
                                                                                                                          beholders a full sight.   Accordingly, when she had pro

                                                                                                                          164                   Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                          ceeded little farther than a stone.s throw, 'Bezerillo.
                                                                                                                          was set at her.    Hearing him come, the woman threw
                                                                                                                          herself on the ground, and her simple faith in Salazar.s
                                                                                                                          intention and in the animal's sagacity saved her; for
                                                                                                                          she held out the letter to the dog, and cried with a loud
                                                                                                                          voice, ' Oh, Sir dog, Sir dog ! I am carrying a letter to
                                                                                                                          the Lord Governor : don't hurt me, Sir dog !'
                                                                                                                             "
                                                                                                                               The dog seemed to understand her, and did under
                                                                                                                          stand her, in fact, sufficiently to know that she did not
                                                                                                                          look upon herself as a condemned person, and that she
                                                                                                                          implored his mercy ; and he came up to her gently and

                                                                                                                          did her no harm."
                                                                                                                                      REMARKABLE       INSTANCE OF FIDELITY.
                                                                                                                            The following anecdote occurs in Washington Ir-
                                                                                                                          ving.s writings   :
                                                                                                                            "In January,        1799, the cold was so intense that the
                                                                                                                          Seine was frozen to the depth of fifteen or sixteen inch
                                                                                                                          es.  Following the example of a number of thoughtless
                                                                                                                          youths, who were determined to continue the amuse
                                                                                                                          ment of skating in spite of a thaw having commenced,
                                                                                                                          a young student, called Beaumanoir, wished also to
                                                                                                                          partake of this dangerous pleasure, near the quay of
                                                                                                                          the Hotel des Monnaies, of Paris ; but he had scarcely
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          gone twenty steps when the ice broke under his weight,
                                                                                                                          and he disappeared.   The young skater had taken his
                                                                                                                          dog with him, which, seeing his master sink under the
                                                                                                                          ice, immediately gave the alarm by barking with all his
                                                                                                                          might, near the spot where the accident had happened.

                    THE FAITHFUL DOG MOURNING HIS LOST MASTER.

Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                    •^
                                                                                          Af rOR. LENOX
                                                                                                                           THE NEW YORK
                                                                                                          PUBLIC LIBRARY
                                                                                      TlLDEN FOUNDATlON

                                                                                                                                       Remarkable Instance   of Fidelity.       167
                                                                                                                          It will easily be believed that it was impossible to give
                                                                                                                          any assistance to the unfortunate youth, but the howl-
                                                                                                                          ings of the animal warned others from approaching the
                                                                                                                          fatal place.   The poor dog sent forth the most fright
                                                                                                                          ful howls ; he ran along the river as if he were mad ;
                                                                                                                          and at last, not seeing his master return, he went to es
                                                                                                                          tablish himself at the hole where he had seen him dis
                                                                                                                          appear, and there he passed the rest of the day and all
                                                                                                                          the following night.     The day after, people saw with
                                                                                                                          surprise the poor animal sorrowfully at the same post.
                                                                                                                          Struck with admiration of such constancy, some of
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          them made him a little bed of straw, and brought him
                                                                                                                          some food ; but, absorbed in the most profound grief,
                                                                                                                          he would not even drink the milk which these kind-
                                                                                                                          hearted people placed near him.      Sometimes he would
                                                                                                                          run about the ice or the borders of the river to seek
                                                                                                                          his master, but he always returned to sleep in the same
                                                                                                                          place.   He bit a soldier who was attempting to make
                                                                                                                          him leave his inhospitable retreat, who, fearing that he
                                                                                                                          was mad, fired at and wounded him.         This affecting
                                                                                                                          example of grief and constancy was witnessed for
                                                                                                                          many days, and people came in crowds to contemplate
                                                                                                                          this beautiful trait of attachment, which was not with
                                                                                                                          out its reward.   The dog, being only slightly wounded,
                                                                                                                          was taken charge of by a woman, who, compassion
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          ating his suffering, and touched by the affection he
                                                                                                                          showed for his late master, carried him to her house,
                                                                                                                          where his wound was dressed, and every effort that
                                                                                                                          kindness could devise was practised to console the
                                                                                                                          faithful animal for the loss of his young master."

                                                                                                                          1   68            •
                                                                                                                                                Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                                        THE ABSCONDING SHEEP.KILLER.
                                                                                                                               "
                                                                                                                              We generally take for granted," says Mr. St. John,
                                                                                                                          in his " Tour in Sutherlandshire," " that dogs and other
                                                                                                                          animals have no anticipation of evil.          I
                                                                                                                                                                    must admit,
                                                                                                                          however, that I  was once told, and by a credible per
                                                                                                                          son, an anecdote which went to impugn this theory.
                                                                                                                          His dog having been convicted of sheep-killing, he told
                                                                                                                          a man to shoot him the following morning.     The dog
                                                                                                                          was lying in the room at the time, and apparently list
                                                                                                                          ening to the conversation.  Whether he understood it
                                                                                                                                   I
                                                                                                                          or not will not pretend to determine ; but the very
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          first time the door was open he bolted out, and never
                                                                                                                          again came within reach of his old master."
                                                                                                                                                THE CHILD.DISCOVERER.
                                                                                                                               Mr. Youatt  relates the following :
                                                                                                                            "A planter had fixed his residence at the foot of the
                                                                                                                          Blue Mountains, in the back settlements of America.
                                                                                                                          One day the youngest of his family, a child about four
                                                                                                                          years old, disappeared.    The father, becoming alarmed,
                                                                                                                          explored the woods in every direction, but without suc
                                                                                                                          cess.  On the following day the search was renewed,
                                                                                                                          during which a native Indian happened to pass, accom
                                                                                                                          panied by his dog, one of the true blood-hound breed.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          Being informed of the distress of the planter, he re
                                                                                                                          quested that the shoes and stockings last worn by the
                                                                                                                          child might be brought to him. He made the dog
                                                                                                                          smell them, and patted him.    The intelligent animal
                                                                                                                          seemed to comprehend all about        for he began im
                                                                                                                                                                  it,

                                                                                                                                   The Shepherd-Dog who died at his Post.      1   69
                                                                                                                          mediately to sniff around.     The Indian and his dog
                                                                                                                          plunged into the wood.    They had not been there long
                                                                                                                          before the dog began to bay : he thought that he had
                                                                                                                          hit upon the scent, and presently afterwards, being as
                                                                                                                          sured of it, he uttered a louder and more expressive
                                                                                                                          note, and darted off at full speed into the forest. The
                                                                                                                          Indian followed, and after a considerable time met his
                                                                                                                          dog bounding back, his noble countenance beaming
                                                                                                                          with animation.     The hound turned again into the
                                                                                                                          wood, his master being not far behind, and they found
                                                                                                                          the child lying at the foot of a tree fatigued and ex
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          hausted, but otherwise unhurt."
                                                                                                                                   THE SHEPHERD .DOG WHO DIED AT HIS POST.
                                                                                                                            The Rev. T. Young relates     the following anecdote   :
                                                                                                                            "A   shepherd had driven part of his flock to a neigh
                                                                                                                          boring fair, leaving his dog to watch the remainder
                                                                                                                          during that day and the next night, expecting to rejoin
                                                                                                                          them the following morning. Unfortunately, however,
                                                                                                                          when at the fair, the shepherd forgot both his dog and
                                                                                                                          his sheep, and did not return home till the morning of
                                                                                                                          the third day.   His first inquiry was, whether the dog
                                                                                                                          had been seen.      The answer was 'No.' 'Then he
                                                                                                                          must be dead,' replied the shepherd, with a tone and
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          gesture of anguish, for      know he was too faithful to
                                                                                                                                              '
                                                                                                                                                  I
                                                                                                                          desert his charge.'  He instantly repaired to the heath.
                                                                                                                          The dog had just sufficient strength remaining to crawl
                                                                                                                          to his master's feet and express his joy at his return,
                                                                                                                          and almost immediately expired."

                                                                                                                          170               Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                                              GENEROUS REVENGE.
                                                                                                                            There    is a story of a person who, being desirous of
                                                                                                                          getting rid of his dog, took it along with him in a boat,
                                                                                                                          and, rowing out into the River Seine, threw it overboard.
                                                                                                                          The poor animal repeatedly struggled to regain the
                                                                                                                          boat, but was as often beaten off, till at length, in his at
                                                                                                                          tempts to baffle the efforts of the dog, the man upset
                                                                                                                          the boat and fell into the water.   No sooner, however,
                                                                                                                          did the generous animal see his master struggle in the
                                                                                                                          stream than he forsook the boat, and held him above
                                                                                                                          water till assistance arrived, and thus saved his life.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          Was not this dog morally superior to his owner in thus
                                                                                                                          returning good for evil ?
                                                                                                                                                 FISH.CATCHERS.

                                                                                                                                                                                 ap
                                                                                                                          parently as much at their ease in the water as on the

                                                                                                                                              THE CARRIER'S DOG.
                                                                                                                            Mr. L. Hannaford,      a correspondent    of The Natu
                                                                                                                          ralist, sent me the following :
                                                                                                                             "A farmer residing near Worksop, Nottinghamshire,
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          had a dog which had formerly been the property of a
                                                                                                                          carrier, and in the habit of accompanying his master to
                                                                                                                          market with a cart every Saturday; but, although he
                                                                                                                          had changed masters, he did not forget his old habits,
                                                                                                                          and every Friday night started off to the carrier's
                                                                                                                          residence to accompany him on the Saturday.     He al
                                                                                                                          ways returned home on Sunday morning, and general
                                                                                                                          ly brought something in his mouth, as if to satisfy his
                                                                                                                          master as to the cause of his absence."
                                                                                                                                               BRAVE "NEPTUNE."
                                                                                                                            The light-house of Dungeness stands upon         the ex
                                                                                                                          treme point of Romney Marsh, and is of great benefit
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          to sailors, for when a storm is driving along the Chan
                                                                                                                          nel the Romney shore is very dangerous.    After a se
                                                                                                                          vere tempest, during which many vessels were wrecked
                                                                                                                          on the shores of Kent, a large wild-looking dog was
                                                                                                                          seen wandering about the beach in the neighborhood

                                                                                                                          172                    Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                          of Dungeness.          He was supposed    to be the sole living
                                                                                                                          being which had escaped from some unfortunate wreck.
                                                                                                                          In appearance he so much resembled a wolf, that, when
                                                                                                                          first seen, he was fired at by some one who was inter
                                                                                                                          ested in the safety of the Romney sheep.
                                                                                                                              "
                                                                                                                                Neptune," as the dog was afterwards named, came
                                                                                                                          into the possession of James Cooper Procter, Esq., of
                                                                                                                          Rose Cottage, Lydd, a village distant about three miles
                                                                                                                                               "         "
                                                                                                                          from Dungeness.        Neptune was very fond of asso
                                                                                                                          ciating with the fishermen and coast guard, but, per
                                                                                                                          haps vividly remembering the tempest which had driv
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          en him ashore, he showed a decided aversion to enter
                                                                                                                          the water, which no coaxing or threatening could over
                                                                                                                          come. He even avoided the little pools made by the
                                                                                                                          rain in the ruts of the roads.
                                                                                                                              The night of the 24th October, 1855, was one in
                                                                                                                          which the storm swept in its fury along the shores of
                                                                                                                          Kent. On the following morning many of the inhab
                                                                                                                          itants of Lydd, on being informed by the light-house
                                                                                                                          keepers that a vessel, which proved to be the Enchant
                                                                                                                          ress, was driving swiftly shoreward, hurried down to
                                                                                                                          the beach to render what assistance they might to the
                                                                                                                          crew,   if any still
                                                                                                                                           survived.   Mr. Procter, in his capacity
                                                                                                                                                                     "
                                                                                                                          as surgeon, rode down, accompanied by Neptune," to
                                                                                                                          tender his professional services.

                                                                                                                          a deep hole scooped out by the wash of the sea.    Mr.
                                                                                                                          Procter freed himself from the stirrups, and made many

                                                                                                                                               Brave "Neptune?                 175
                                                                                                                          vain efforts to get to land.   Twice he was ingulfed by
                                                                                                                          the waves, and was    exhausted and nearly insensible,
                                                                                                                          when " Neptune," who had been running up and down
                                                                                                                          the beach at a considerable distance from the waves,
                                                                                                                          as if calling his master to come ashore, dashed in
                                                                                                                          among them, and attempted frequently, but vainly, to
                                                                                                                          seize him by the collar of his upper coat, but the smooth
                                                                                                                          surface of the coat, a water-proof, rendered his efforts
                                                                                                                          useless.
                                                                                                                             Mr. Procter was about to sink for
                                                                                                                                                             the last time, when
                                                                                                                          he fancied he heard some one shout, " Lay hold of his
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          tail   !"Scarcely knowing what he was about, he did
                                                                                                                                      "    "
                                                                                                                          so.     Neptune doubled round, licked his hand, and
                                                                                                                          turned and made for the shore, towing his unconscious
                                                                                                                          master.    With much difficulty they both reached the
                                                                                                                          land in safety.
                                                                                                                              Mr. Procter was carried to the inn, where restora
                                                                                                                                                 "          "
                                                                                                                          tives were applied.      Neptune     would not quit his
                                                                                                                          side, but laid himself on the bed, and there remained
                                                                                                                          for a long time, until enticed from the apartment and
                                                                                                                          induced to go home.      On the following morning, as
                                                                                                                          soon as the inn was opened, he ran up stairs, and lay
                                                                                                                          outside the bedroom waiting to be allowed to enter.
                                                                                                                          "
                                                                                                                            Neptune," up to the time of his death, always slept
                                                                                                                          outside his master's bedroom.    Previous to the day of
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          the wreck of the Enchantress, " Neptune," though his
                                                                                                                          master's companion in his rides, was not even allowed
                                                                                                                          to enter the house. From that day forward he never
                                                                                                                          would permit his master to go out alone. When Mr.
                                                                                                                          Procter, in any of his winter rides, was obliged to pass

                                                                                                                          176              Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                                                       "              "
                                                                                                                          through the flooded meadows,   Neptune always pilot
                                                                                                                          ed the way.
                                                                                                                             "Neptune" died in 1861. One day he was seen to
                                                                                                                          disappear among the furze above the sea-shore, and
                                                                                                                          evening came and morning followed, but he did not re
                                                                                                                          turn home.    Three days passed away, when a young
                                                                                                                          man came to tell Mr. and Mrs. Procter, to their great
                                                                                                                          grief, that he had found the dead body of "Neptune"
                                                                                                                          on the beach.    The faithful animal had died of an af
                                                                                                                          fection of the heart.  His body was carried to Lydd,
                                                                                                                          and buried in his master.s garden ; and over his grave
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          was placed a tablet in grateful remembrance of his ex
                                                                                                                          traordinary worth and affection.
                                                                                                                                           INCONSOLABLE   MOURNERS.
                                                                                                                            A minister of     a parish in Sutherlandshire having
                                                                                                                          died, his favorite dog followed his body to the grave,
                                                                                                                          and no inducement could persuade the faithful animal
                                                                                                                          to leave the place.   Night and day, bad weather and
                                                                                                                          good, did the dog remain stretched on the grave.     The
                                                                                                                          people of the neighborhood, finding all their endeavors
                                                                                                                          to entice him away fruitless, and respecting his fidelity,
                                                                                                                          fed and protected him.      This continued for several
                                                                                                                          weeks — indeed until some time after the manse was
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          tenanted by a new minister, whose wife, from some
                                                                                                                          wretched feeling of superstition, caused the dog to be
                                                                                                                          killed.  Mr. Charles St. John, who relates this fact in
                                                                                                                               "
                                                                                                                          his Tour in Sutherlandshire," adds, " May the mourn
                                                                                                                          ers over her own grave be better treated !"
