                                                                                                                          ther.s dog, Jem,' who was not renowned as a fighting
                                                                                                                                     '
                                                                                                                          dog, and having sometimes to pay a visit to some ca
                                                                                                                          nine friend in the locality, he would have to pass the
                                                                                                                          parsonage-house, where was a dog a little too much
                                                                                                                                                            '
                                                                                                                          for ' Jem,' but afraid of ' Jem's companion, ' Carlo,.
                                                                                                                          who, therefore, on being politely requested by ' Jem,.
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          used to escort him past the other, and then return
                                                                                                                          home.    '
                                                                                                                                     Jem' was a dog well known for miles round —
                                                                                                                          a dog that would not be picked up by any one : and that
                                                                                                                          fact renders the following still more wonderful.  Doc
                                                                                                                          tor M..s father was on his death-bed ; Jem,' who was
                                                                                                                                                                 '

                                                                                                                                             "Faithful. 'Jem:"                 179
                                                                                                                          ardently attached to his master, could not be kept from
                                                                                                                          the chamber.    Immediately Mr. M. breathed his last,
                                                                                                                          the groom was started on horseback to inform the sis
                                                                                                                          ter.   The groom, as was his custom, whistled and
                                                                                                                          called for 'Jem,. but to no purpose.     Returned from
                                                                                                                          his journey of seven or eight miles, he was asked if the
                                                                                                                          dog did not go with him.     No; he had not seen him.
                                                                                                                          The crier was employed, the dog was advertised, and
                                                                                                                          was well known, but never was seen or heard of from
                                                                                                                          the moment the soul of his master had left its earthly
                                                                                                                          tenement.   Will any one say that the faithful creature

                                                                                                                                          THE FAITHFUL BLIND DOG.
                                                                                                                            Here is another anecdote, similar to the foregoing   :
                                                                                                                            "A   gentleman was obliged to go a journey periodic
                                                                                                                          ally.  His stay was short, and his departure and re
                                                                                                                          turn were true to the appointed time.     The dog' was
                                                                                                                          always uneasy when he first lost his master, and moped
                                                                                                                          in a corner, but recovered gradually as the time for his
                                                                                                                          return approached; and when he was certain that his
                                                                                                                          owner was not far from home, he bounded away to
                                                                                                                          meet him.    At length the old gentleman grew infirm,
                                                                                                                          and incapable of continuing his journeys.        The dog
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                          by this time was also grown old, and became at length
                                                                                                                          quite blind ; but this misfortune did not hinder him from
                                                                                                                          fondling upon his aged master, whom he knew from all
                                                                                                                          other persons.  The old gentleman died. The dog
                                                                                                                          watched the corpse, blind as he was, and did his utmost

                                                                                                                          i8o             Dogs and their Doings.
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                          to prevent the undertaker from screwing up the body
                                                                                                                          in the coffin. He now grew disconsolate, lost his flesh,
                                                                                                                          and was evidently verging towards his end."

                                                                                                                                           "Please, give me a        Drink P             183
                                                                                                                                                          I
                                                                                                                          noticed a label, on which read the words, 'Please, give
                                                                                                                          me a drink!'
                                                                                                                             " No sooner had attention been called to this
                                                                                                                                                                           appeal,
                                                                                                                          evidently attached to the dog's neck by a kind-hearted
                                                                                                                          and thoughtful owner, than a group of ladies and chil
                                                                                                                          dren gathered around us, and willing hands and feet
                                                                                                                          were in instant requisition to provide a supply of water.
                                                                                                                          One of the porters, evidently with a tender heart under
                                                                                                                          his fustian, promptly brought a tin filled with water,
                                                                                                                          which was quickly drunk by the thirsty animal, whose
                                                                                                                          face  said, as plainly as dog can say, ' Thank you !'
Generated for acobblah (University of Michigan) on 2015-10-29 19:28 GMT / http://hdl.handle.net/2027/nyp.33433010906554
                                                                                                                                                     I
                                                                                                                          Several of the ladies, found, were to be fellow-passen
                                                                                                                          gers with the dog, and many were the assurances from
                                                                                                                          my fair friends that doggie should have every attention
                                                                                                                          during the voyage, and should not suffer from the want
                                                                                                                          of either food or water."
                                                                                                                                    Who could behold the motto on his neck
                                                                                                                                      To the chance stranger silently appealing,
                                                                                                                                    Or look into his countenance, and check
                                                                                                                                      The loving action and the tender feeling?
                                                                                                                                   Furnished with such a passport kind and wise,
                                                                                                                                     Friend after friend provides the noble creature
                                                                                                                                   With water for his thirst, while from his eyes
                                                                                                                                     Thanks overflow, and from each speaking. feature.
                                                                                                                                   Ah, if we saw that touching prayer for drink
Public Domain, Google-digitized / http://www.hathitrust.org/access_use#pd-google
                                                                                                                                     Plainly round other thirsty throats suspended,
                                                                                                                                   Would our much.suffering flocks and cattle sink
                                                                                                                                     Along the public ways all unbefriended ?
                                                                                                                                    Hour after hour, in the hot dusty lane,
                                                                                                                                      Would the dumb sheep or ox attract no pity?
                                                                                                                                    And would their patient eyes appeal in vain
                                                                                                                                      From iron railroad, or from stone.paved city.

                                                                                                                          1   84                          Dogs and their Doings.
                                                                                                                                          Thirst! There is One above who knows that pang:
                                                                                                                                            "Give me to drink,." He said to Sychar's daughter;
                                                                                                                                          And from his lips a sad UI thirst!" once rang
                                                                                                                                            When He man.s victim was, and had no water.
                                                                                                                                         Touched    with the feeling of His creatures' grief,
                                                                                                                                              The mighty Maker listens to their groaning ;
